text:
*Need some help mates,*

We have a B2b content marketing agency here in the Middle East. And we mostly work with Marketing managers at mid-sized companies and CEOs of startups. However, there’s a pattern I’m noticing: Our audience doesn’t really understand the value of content marketing.

To them content marketing is just producing a few articles and publishing them on the blog since everyone is doing that. More of the blog and pray approach.

We always use GA to set goals to measure the performance of our SEO-focused content strategy so that we have clear answers for: what’s ROI of this content strategy so far?

Still, the biggest problem is that they just don’t get it. And we’re having an empty sales pipeline. What do you suggest to me to do, in this case?

elements.text:
We have a B2b content marketing agency here in the Middle East. And we mostly work with Marketing managers at mid-sized companies and CEOs of startups. However, there’s a pattern I’m noticing: Our audience doesn’t really understand the value of content marketing.

To them content marketing is just producing a few articles and publishing them on the blog since everyone is doing that. More of the blog and pray approach.

We always use GA to set goals to measure the performance of our SEO-focused content strategy so that we have clear answers for: what’s ROI of this content strategy so far?

Still, the biggest problem is that they just don’t get it. And we’re having an empty sales pipeline. What do you suggest to me to do, in this case?

text: Lots of ideas but if your main value is revenue, then that also has to be your marketing. If they just want some fast/dirty blogs, you’re not right for them.

elements.text: Lots of ideas but if your main value is revenue, then that also has to be your marketing. If they just want some fast/dirty blogs, you’re not right for them.
